title: Rugby World Cup 2019: Kick-off time and TV details for South Africa vs Namibia
text:
South Africa will be looking to bounce back from their Rugby World Cup defeat against New Zealand when they take on Namibia.

Rassie Erasmus’ men were beaten 23-13 on the opening weekend, despite making a promising start against their fierce rivals.

The Springboks take on a Namibia side that will be licking the wounds of their 47-22 loss at the hands of Italy.

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

Erasmus has rung the changes for the clash, with Schalk Brits, who came out of retirement for the World Cup, starting the game at number eight.

Brits has only 13 caps since making his debut in 2008, with Saturday his third start and first appearance at the back of scrum.

When is it?

South Africa vs Namibia kicks off at 6.45pm Japan Standard Time (10.45am BST) on Saturday 28 September.

Where can I watch it?

ITV will be broadcasting the match. Coverage starts at 10.30am.

Alternatively, you can live stream the game via the ITV Hub on your smartphone, desktop or tablet.

Teams

South Africa: Warrick Gelant, Sbu Nkosi, Lukhanyo Am, Frans Steyn, Makazole Mapimpi, Elton Jantjies, Herschel Jantjies; Schalk Brits (captain), Kwagga Smith, Francois Louw, Lood de Jager, RG Snyman, Vincent Koch, Bongi Mbonambi, Tendai Mtawarira.

Reserves: Steven Kitshoff, Thomas du Toit, Eben Etzebeth, Siya Kolisi, Franco Mostert, Cobus Reinach, Damian de Allende, Cheslin Kolbe.

Namibia: Johan Tromp, Chad Plato, JC Greyling, Peter John Walters, Lesley Klim, Cliven Loubser, Eugene Jantjies; Adriaan Booysen, Muharua Katjijeko, Thomasau Forbes, Tjiuee Uanivi (captain), Johan Retief, AJ De Klerk, Louis van der Westhuizen, Desiderius Sethie.

Reserves: Obert Nortje, Andre Rademeyer, Johannes Coetzee, Prince Gaoseb, Janco Venter, Wian Conradie, Helarius Axasman Kisting, Johan Deysel.

Prediction

The Springboks have made 13 changes to the side that ran out against New Zealand as Erasmus looks to keep his men fit and fresh for the latter stages of the competition. Even with a weakened team, there’s no doubt that it’d take something special from Namibia to topple the two-time world champions. Do they have it in their locker? No, probably not. A thumping win for South Africa.
